channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Georgia Supreme Court declines to reinstate election rules approved by Trump-allied board that critics warned could cause chaos
item.description: The decision is yet another legal setback for the state election board, which sought to implement an array of changes in the weeks and months before the November vote.

item.title: E. coli outbreak linked to McDonald’s Quarter Pounders, CDC says
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating an E. coli outbreak that has sickened 49 people in 10 states, including one person who has died. McDonald’s has stopped using fresh slivered onions and quarter-pound beef patties in several states while the investigation continues into which food ingredient is contaminated.

item.title: Antetokounmpo, Doncic or Jokic? See who’s No. 1 on our list of the top 100 NBA players as a new season tips off.
item.description: The 2024-25 NBA season starts tonight. Here’s our annual look at the league’s best players.

item.title: More Republicans appear to be voting early after Trump pivots to encourage it
item.description: GOP participation seems to at least partially reflect former president Donald Trump’s change of heart on early voting, which he slammed without evidence in 2020 as riddled with fraud but has heavily promoted this campaign season.

item.title: Live chat: Are the Commanders legitimate contenders? Post sportswriters are answering readers’ questions now.
item.description: With a 5-2 record, Washington has been one of the top teams in the NFL this season, but it received a scare Sunday when rookie QB Jayden Daniels exited a victory with a rib injury. Sports columnist Barry Svrluga and Commanders beat writers Nicki Jhabvala and Sam Fortier are answering fans’ questions ahead of this weekend’s matchup against No. 1 pick Caleb Williams and the Chicago Bears.

item.title: How good are you at spotting misinformation online? Test yourself with these 8 questions.
item.description: Misinformation is everywhere this election. See how well you can identify falsehoods — and how you stack up against other readers.

item.title: Voters prefer Harris’s agenda to Trump’s. They just don’t realize it. Take this quiz to see how well you align with each candidate.
item.description: Try our interactive quiz to see how well you (and other voters) align with each candidate’s agenda.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Anxious mother-in-law is seriously ill. Doesn’t positivity help?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Anxious mother-in-law is seriously ill. Doesn’t positivity help?

item.title: Ex-CEO of Abercrombie & Fitch arrested on sex trafficking charges
item.description: Former Abercrombie & Fitch chief executive Mike Jeffries was arrested Tuesday along with his romantic partner, Matt Smith, and another man, Jim Jacobson, in connection with a criminal sex trafficking investigation, according to two people familiar with the case.

item.title: A title for this team — but not without controversy — in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Alleged leak of U.S. intel on Israel’s potential Iran attack plan is under investigation by the FBI
item.description: The FBI said it is working with the Defense Department and intelligence agencies to probe the possible leak of classified material. Over the weekend, multiple news organizations reported that the documents contained information about Israel’s potential plans for a retaliatory attack on Iran, which sent a barrage of missiles into Israel on Oct. 1.

item.title: Harris campaign. Central Park Five. Washington state shooting. Israeli strike. Consent law. Student loans. NBA. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: A 13-year-old gave birth. Idaho’s parental consent law snagged her care.
item.description: The state’s new law requires parental permission for nearly all health care a minor receives. A young teen’s pregnancy got caught up in the consequences.

item.title: A viral attack on Tim Walz features video of a man using a former student’s name to make false claims
item.description: The real former student, a Hawaii man who attended a school where the vice-presidential candidate formerly taught, told The Washington Post that they never met and that he was dismayed to see the video. Millions of people have viewed social media posts containing the video since it was published last week on X.

item.title: This type of home could reinvent the American Dream and help fix the housing crisis
item.description: Americans are desperate for more affordable and low-maintenance housing options

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Teen son is nasty to his parents, polite to the rest of the world
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Teen son is nasty to his parents, polite to the rest of the world

item.title: Trans youth who received gender-affirming care were largely satisfied with the treatments, survey finds
item.description: A survey of more than 200 transgender and nonbinary youth who received gender-affirming medical care, such as puberty blockers and hormones, shows they were largely satisfied with the treatments they received, according to a study published Monday in JAMA Pediatrics, with only 4 percent — nine respondents — expressing some form of regret.

item.title: College athletes are finally getting paid. A Post analysis reveals the winners and losers of this hidden economy.
item.description: The Washington Post obtained and analyzed public records from power conference schools to reveal how boosters and corporations are doling out “name, image and likeness” money to college athletes — and how this hidden economy is fueling disparities.

item.title: Hacking into this archive in today's On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Harris and Trump locked in dead heat in seven battleground states, Washington Post-Schar School poll finds
item.description: The survey of more than 5,000 registered voters finds former president Donald Trump strongest in Arizona while Vice President Kamala Harris shows strength in Georgia. With two weeks to the election, some voters are still deciding, with more 18-to-25-year-olds uncommitted than those in other age groups.

item.title: Presidential polls. Birth control. Israeli strike. Historic rainfall. Home prices. WNBA Finals. Pyramid dog. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Los Angeles Dodgers win the National League pennant, setting up a star-studded World Series with the New York Yankees
item.description: The Dodgers finished off the New York Mets in six games Sunday night and will face the Yankees in the best-of-seven World Series beginning Friday in Los Angeles. The high-profile matchup pits Shohei Ohtani, Mookie Betts and the Dodgers against Aaron Judge, Juan Soto and the Yankees for Major League Baseball's championship.

item.title: New York Liberty wins WNBA championship, defeating Minnesota Lynx in five games
item.description: The Liberty prevailed in overtime in the winner-take-all Game 5 on Sunday night in Brooklyn to capture its first league title in its sixth trip to the Finals. After falling in last year's championship series, New York had the best record in the WNBA this year.

item.title: Quarterback Jayden Daniels exits Commanders' game with apparent rib injury
item.description: The star rookie, who guided Washington to a 4-2 record entering Sunday, left in the first quarter against the Carolina Panthers. The severity of his injury is not yet clear. The Commanders lead the Panthers 27-0 at halftime. Follow our live file for updates.

item.title: Voters in must-win Pennsylvania are full of doubt, anger and unease
item.description: The Post drove 1,000 miles talking to voters in the most critical battleground state and found worries about Kamala Harris, fears about Donald Trump and uncertainty all over.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: The whistleblower who triggered Trump’s first impeachment asks: Was it worth it?
item.description: The CIA analyst’s lonely stand upended his career and put his life at risk. Now he’s speaking about it for the first time.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Homeowners love rooftop solar panels. But there’s a problem.
item.description: As more and more homeowners turn to solar, thanks in part to more generous government incentives, it could become more expensive for the United States to meet its overall climate goals.

item.title: Would you be fooled by deepfakes of Trump and Harris? Test yourself.
item.description: Artificial intelligence has made it easy to copy someone’s voice, allowing thousands of audio impersonations to flood the internet this election year. Here’s how to tell what’s real.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: I’m a manager with no real power. How do I support my employees?
item.description: Ask Sahaj: I’m a manager with no real power. How do I support my employees?

item.title: Boeing and union leaders reach tentative deal to end machinists’ strike with a proposal that calls for a 35 percent pay hike
item.description: The 33,000 machinists on strike will vote Wednesday on whether to approve the deal brokered with the help of acting Labor Secretary Julie Su. The work stoppage has halted production of some of the company’s top-selling jets and led the company to furlough thousands of employees.

item.title: The Putin-backed strongman who threw the Paris Games into chaos with a boxing ‘gender controversy’
item.description: Banned from the Games, Russia wanted to upend the Olympics. Enter Umar Kremlev and a fierce battle over "gender tests" allegedly failed by two women boxers.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Many Americans are ‘car poor’ from their auto loans. Our personal finance columnist explains why.
item.description: Nearly 1 in 4 consumers owe more on such loans than the vehicle is worth. Some are also opting to stretch their monthly car payments far longer than what used to be the traditional four-year loan. But consumers can find a car they can afford, and columnist Michelle Singletary explains how.

item.title: Crashes involving Tesla’s Full Self-Driving prompt new federal probe of system’s use in low-visibility conditions
item.description: Car safety regulators opened an investigation into four crashes, including one that killed a pedestrian. The new probe appears to be taking a more direct look at the technology underpinning the Full Self-Driving system, which relies on cameras to guide Tesla vehicles without the aid of other kinds of sensors. The system is available in more than 2 million vehicles, though not all Tesla owners pay for the FSD package.

item.title: Trump hotel sometimes charged Secret Service 300 percent or more above government rates during his presidency, House Democrats find
item.description: Trump’s D.C. hotel sometimes charged the protective agency more than it did other patrons, including a foreign royal family, House Democrats found. Republicans dismissed the report as misleading and outdated.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.

item.title: Hamas leader. Harris vs. Trump. Secret Service. Postponed execution. Winter weather. Subscriptions. Mount Vernon. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: How just saying ‘vote’ can cause Instagram to suppress your posts
item.description: Washington Post tech columnist Geoffrey Fowler shows how Meta’s Instagram, Facebook and Threads are reducing content related to the election in people’s feeds.

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs threw parties like a ‘modern-day Gatsby.’ New accusations cast the star-studded events in a dark light.
item.description: Until recently, most of the abuse accusations against Combs had focused on the alleged sex parties he called “freak-offs.” Now his troubles have prompted a closer examination of his White Parties, which one accuser says had a sinister side from the very beginning.

item.title: Virginia men’s basketball coach Tony Bennett to retire, effective immediately
item.description: Bennett, 55, will announce his retirement during a news conference Friday morning, the basketball program announced on Thursday. The unexpected news comes just weeks before Bennett was set to begin his 16th season with the Cavaliers. He is one of the most decorated active coaches in the country, guiding Virginia to two ACC tournament titles and the 2019 national championship.

item.title: Mitzi Gaynor dies at 93. The song-and-dance queen starred in 1950s Hollywood musicals such as ‘South Pacific.’
item.description: The vivacious Hollywood musical star later gained a wide following with TV variety-show specials and her long-running cabaret act.

item.title: Grand jury formally indicts alleged Georgia school shooter, 14, and his father on dozens of additional charges
item.description: Colt Gray, the accused shooter, was arrested and charged last month with four counts of felony murder for allegedly shooting and killing two students and two teachers on Sept. 4 at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga. A Barrow County grand jury indicted him on 55 counts tied to the shooting, which wounded nine other students. Colin Gray, the alleged shooter’s father who was arrested and charged last month on second-degree murder and manslaughter charges, was indicted by the same grand jury on 29 total charges.

item.title: Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, architect of the Oct. 7 attacks, killed in Gaza, Israeli official confirms
item.description: Sinwar planned last year’s deadly assault on southern Israel, setting off a devastating war in Gaza that has rippled across the Middle East. He was killed by the Israeli military in Gaza after eluding their forces for more than a year, and his body was identified after DNA testing in Israel, an Israeli official said. Hamas did not immediately confirm his death.

item.title: Trump says Ukrainian President Zelensky ‘should never have let that war start’ with Russia
item.description: Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022. Former president Donald Trump made his comment in a podcast published Thursday. Trump has reportedly maintained a relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin since leaving the White House and said this week that “Russia has never had a president that they respect so much.”

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Do good husbands leave the ‘half-dressed’ damsels on the stoop?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Do good husbands leave the ‘half-dressed’ damsels on the stoop?

item.title: Five key moments from Kamala Harris’s heated Fox News interview
item.description: Harris sparred with Fox chief political anchor Bret Baier as they discussed issues including immigration, gender-affirming surgery and her differences with President Joe Biden.

item.title: Israel is investigating whether Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar was killed. A body has been taken for DNA testing, Israeli official says.
item.description: The Israeli military says Sinwar, the architect of the Oct. 7 attacks, may have been killed in Gaza.

item.title: A multifaceted history lesson in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.
